episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the different responses and countermeasures that can be employed to protect against network based attacks. Here they will cover network segmentation strategies, specifically the use of system isolation. This will cover the pros and cons of system isolation and then explore the use of Jump Boxes and Secure Admin Workstations.
episodes.title: Countermeasures: Network Segmentation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the different responses and countermeasures that can be employed to protect against network based attacks. Here they look into using Honeypots and DNS Sinkholes to that end. Honeypots to help reveal how a network is being targeted/attacked and Sinkholes which can be an effective tactic for stoping malware from connecting to Command&Control servers.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the different responses and countermeasures that can be employed to protect against network based attacks. out of the scanning schedule.

460
00:23:29.840 --> 00:23:32.620
So everything's getting
scanned ultimately but

461
00:23:32.620 --> 00:23:34.150
not everything is getting
scanned at the same time.

462
00:23:34.150 --> 00:23:37.280
And this can help with performance and
network utilization and

463
00:23:37.280 --> 00:23:38.480
things of that nature.

464
00:23:38.480 --> 00:23:40.890
So revolving scans might
be the exact fit for

465
00:23:40.890 --> 00:23:46.630
your organization to help keep the
utilization of your network bandwidth and

466
00:23:46.630 --> 00:23:49.060
CPU and Ram and all that other good stuff.

467
00:23:49.060 --> 00:23:54.281
All your performance issues might at
least come down to a more acceptable

468
00:23:54.281 --> 00:23:58.916
level than if you were to just scan
the whole network at one time.

469
00:23:58.916 --> 00:24:03.049
Also set it to where it scans as
a revolving scan when the resource becomes

470
00:24:03.049 --> 00:24:04.570
available.

471
00:24:04.570 --> 00:24:06.761
So resources are available to scan this.

472
00:24:06.761 --> 00:24:09.110
Let's go ahead and
do that while we have it.

473
00:24:09.110 --> 00:24:13.110
So maybe scans are running at night, and
you're only doing a specific portion.

474
00:24:13.110 --> 00:24:15.850
And then, tomorrow night,
it'll run another specific portion, and so

475
00:24:15.850 --> 00:24:16.840
on and so forth.

476
00:24:16.840 --> 00:24:20.620
So I'm not affecting my
production performance.

477
00:24:20.620 --> 00:24:23.730
>> Let's see here, because resources can

478
00:24:23.730 --> 00:24:28.770
be bandwidth-intensive It's also
better for early detection.

479
00:24:28.770 --> 00:24:32.360
So the more often you scan,
the more likely you

480
00:24:32.360 --> 00:24:37.130
are to detect something before
it becomes an actual problem.

481
00:24:37.130 --> 00:24:41.210
So that's gonna weigh in on
how frequently should we scan?

482
00:24:41.210 --> 00:24:44.990
And that's going to be directly
correlated to your risk appetite,

483
00:24:44.990 --> 00:24:45.510
to be honest with you.

484
00:24:45.510 --> 00:24:48.540
If your risk appetite is low,
then you're gonna scan more often.

485
00:24:48.540 --> 00:24:52.890
If your risk appetite is high, then, hey,
we live in a world where there's risk.

486
00:24:52.890 --> 00:24:53.790
What are you gonna do, right?

487
00:24:53.790 --> 00:24:55.130
And you might not scan as much.

489
00:25:00.920 --> 00:25:04.150

00:25:04.150 --> 00:25:06.070
I can go in there, create that schedule.

492

495
00:25:23.080 --> 00:25:25.160
How do we work with continuous monitoring?

496
00:25:25.160 --> 00:25:26.950

You're gonna have to be able

a report back to the command server so

512

that's a great question.
>> So what Zach is alluding to is

00:01:36.563 --> 00:01:38.823

47
00:01:55.371 --> 00:01:57.823
But in reality, it's not.

48
00:01:57.823 --> 00:02:01.862
So it's a good reason that we should
be doing the verification of these

49
00:02:01.862 --> 00:02:04.742
vulnerabilities that
the scanner has produced.

50
00:02:04.742 --> 00:02:09.253
Well my vulnerability scanner
is a perfect being that

51
00:02:09.253 --> 00:02:12.745
never gets anything wrong.
>> [LAUGH]

52
00:02:12.745 --> 00:02:13.788
>> [LAUGH] That's not true,

53
00:02:13.788 --> 00:02:14.886
it was created by people.

54
00:02:14.886 --> 00:02:17.416
We're all flawed,
everything has its flaws in it.

55
00:02:17.416 --> 00:02:21.125
So we have to do our
due diligence to find.

56
00:02:21.125 --> 00:02:24.756
False positives is a big problem
when it comes to the scan.

57
00:02:24.756 --> 00:02:28.549
You'd hate to be running down, or chasing
after ghosts, when they don't even exist.

58
00:02:28.549 --> 00:02:29.356
>> Mm-hm.

59
00:02:29.356 --> 00:02:31.476
>> So we have to figure out whether or

60
00:02:31.476 --> 00:02:36.476
not every one of these things are true
as the vulnerability scanner says it is,

61
00:02:36.476 --> 00:02:37.556
or are they not?

62
00:02:37.556 --> 00:02:40.781
Now we can do that really easily,
right off the cuff, by saying,

00:02:46.654 --> 00:02:49.610

00:02:49.610 --> 00:02:52.209

67
00:02:52.209 --> 00:02:53.611
>> Mm-hm.

68
00:02:53.611 --> 00:02:54.654
>> Why does this happen, right?

69
00:02:54.654 --> 00:02:58.765
That's Zach's original question,
why do we get these false positives?

70
00:02:58.765 --> 00:03:03.627
Well because our vulnerable scanners are
not perfect beings that doing everything

71
00:03:03.627 --> 00:03:07.386
exactly right every time,
they have their own issues, right?

72
00:03:07.386 --> 00:03:11.128
So maybe the plugin had an error, right?

73
00:03:11.128 --> 00:03:15.925
So the plugin that looks for said
vulnerability, just had an error in it.

74
00:03:15.925 --> 00:03:17.777
And you gotta update, you got to go out.

75
00:03:17.777 --> 00:03:20.853
Maybe you don't have the latest version
of all the plugins that you have, and

76
00:03:20.853 --> 00:03:23.856
you gotta do your updates, something
like that could cause that problem.

77
00:03:23.856 --> 00:03:25.208
>> Is it unheard of to have a scanner for

78
00:03:25.208 --> 00:03:27.483
your scanner?
>> [LAUGH] A scanner for your scanner?

79
00:03:27.483 --> 00:03:28.142
>> [LAUGH]

80
00:03:28.142 --> 00:03:29.590
>> Actually, they're typically built in to

81
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:31.273
say, check for updates.
>> Run it, right?

82
00:03:31.273 --> 00:03:31.959
>> So you can do that.

83
00:03:31.959 --> 00:03:35.168
You can check for updates, or maybe they
automatically update themselves, once,

84
00:03:35.168 --> 00:03:37.080
twice, three times a day,
whatever the case is.

85
00:03:37.080 --> 00:03:41.029
But whatever it is, make sure before
you run your scans, that everything's

86
00:03:41.029 --> 00:03:44.695
up-to-date, cuz this will alleviate
false positives as a problem.

87
00:03:44.695 --> 00:03:50.962
Doesn't completely remove it,
but it will help lower that down.

88
00:03:50.962 --> 00:03:52.108
All updates are done.

89
00:03:52.108 --> 00:03:57.022
Have you ever called a tech support for
any kind of software or system,

00:03:57.022 --> 00:04:01.619

92
00:04:03.211 --> 00:04:03.985
Is it up-to-date?

93
00:04:03.985 --> 00:04:05.044

00:04:06.714 --> 00:04:08.868
Well an update came out to two days ago,

96
00:04:08.868 --> 00:04:09.444
Well no.

97
00:04:09.444 --> 00:04:12.093
Run that, and then call us back.
>> Marathon.

98
00:04:12.093 --> 00:04:13.208
>> I was working at Enterprise

99
00:04:13.208 --> 00:04:14.367
environment.
>> Mm-hm.

100
00:04:14.367 --> 00:04:16.159
>> If you call tech support, and

101
00:04:16.159 --> 00:04:20.186
you are not on the latest version,
they will tell you, bye-bye.

102
00:04:20.186 --> 00:04:20.808
>> Bye-bye.

103
00:04:20.808 --> 00:04:21.590
>> Thanks for playing,

104
00:04:21.590 --> 00:04:23.204
call us back when that version's updated.

105
00:04:23.204 --> 00:04:27.554
And it really burns you when you
update the thing, and then it works,

106
00:04:27.554 --> 00:04:29.650
you're like.
>> [LAUGH]

107
00:04:29.650 --> 00:04:30.184
>> Then you have no one to

108
00:04:30.184 --> 00:04:30.788
blame, but yourself.

109
00:04:30.788 --> 00:04:33.142
But that is the case.
>> Yeah.

110
00:04:33.142 --> 00:04:33.701
>> What else?

111
00:04:33.701 --> 00:04:37.211

or authorization,

112
00:04:37.211 --> 00:04:41.744

not that vulnerability is there, and

00:04:41.744 --> 00:04:44.757

114
00:04:44.757 --> 00:04:48.747
So you weren't actually able to punch
through and verify it with the scanner,

115
00:04:48.747 --> 00:04:50.511
the scanner wasn't able to do it.

116
00:04:50.511 --> 00:04:53.327
But it has a good indication
that might be a problem.

117
00:04:53.327 --> 00:04:55.576
So it flagged it, and
it put it in your report.

118
00:04:55.576 --> 00:04:59.712
Well now you've got to go verify, well,
okay, yeah, but you'd have to be here, and

00:04:59.712 --> 00:05:01.705
then that, so it can't happen that way.

00:05:01.705 --> 00:05:04.608
And you would verify that

121
00:05:04.608 --> 00:05:07.152
Let's see here,

00:05:07.152 --> 00:05:10.769
I think as far as false positives go,

00:05:15.193 --> 00:05:16.287
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

00:05:16.287 --> 00:05:17.545
>> [LAUGH] Is very important,

00:05:17.545 --> 00:05:19.904
how do we verify?
>> Yeah, that's a great question,

00:05:19.904 --> 00:05:21.436

>> Yeah.

128
00:05:21.436 --> 00:05:21.989
>> We actually kind of

00:05:31.982 --> 00:05:38.096

Well the idea that false positives occur,

00:05:41.091 --> 00:05:44.000

00:05:44.000 --> 00:05:44.551
So we must verify.

00:05:44.551 --> 00:05:47.242
Just because the scanner

00:05:47.242 --> 00:05:51.024

139
00:05:51.024 --> 00:05:52.664
So we gotta do that verification.

140
00:05:52.664 --> 00:05:56.778
That's the reason that we perform
these assessments of whether or

141
00:05:56.778 --> 00:06:00.020

142
00:06:00.020 --> 00:06:01.212
So we have to be doing that.

143
00:06:01.212 --> 00:06:06.189
And it can also point you in
the right direction, that's what it's

00:06:06.189 --> 00:06:11.268

a guideline of where something might be.

145
00:06:11.268 --> 00:06:15.776
It is our job, as security professionals,
to make sure that we covered every base.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore many of the common vulnerabilities that must be understood by a cyber security practitioner. Here they will give explanations to vulnerabilities against servers, workstations, and network infrastructure. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike tackle defining incident severity and prioritization. Here they will look at different impact scopes like functional impact, data integrity impact, and economic impact as well as discussing the different types of data that could lend to the impact severity. This includes Personally Identifiable Information(PII), Personal Health Information(PHI), Payment Card Information, and Intellectual Property.

there is probably some secure mechanisms.

355
00:18:12.380 --> 00:18:17.130
But don't rest on the fact that
probably it's there, know for a fact.

356
00:18:17.130 --> 00:18:18.050
Remember, if you get audited,

357
00:18:18.050 --> 00:18:20.850
the auditor's gonna want
you to prove it to them.

358
00:18:20.850 --> 00:18:24.912
As Missouri would say, show me,
show me don't tell me.

359
00:18:24.912 --> 00:18:27.280
I wanna see it, I wanna see
the controls that are in place.

360
00:18:27.280 --> 00:18:28.980
I wanna make sure that they are working.

361
00:18:28.980 --> 00:18:33.160
You should have that mindset any
time you bring in anything new, and

362
00:18:33.160 --> 00:18:35.540
when you are designing
a system from the out.

363
00:18:35.540 --> 00:18:38.920
So if you're designing
a network from the outset,

364
00:18:38.920 --> 00:18:42.560
and you say we're going to employ
some form of cloud service.

365
00:18:42.560 --> 00:18:44.270
Well how's that gonna connect
to our on-prem service?

366
00:18:44.270 --> 00:18:45.310
Do we have an on-prem service?

367
00:18:45.310 --> 00:18:46.070
Is it all in the cloud?

368
00:18:47.080 --> 00:18:51.960
Ideas and thoughts that you have to be
processing as you design that network out.

369
00:18:51.960 --> 00:18:55.731
So if you are using this as IS,
right, the infrastructure of service.

370
00:18:55.731 --> 00:18:59.345
If I am bringing in some
infrastructure from a cloud service,

371
00:18:59.345 --> 00:19:01.090
how is that being connected?

372
00:19:01.090 --> 00:19:04.510
Is there any kind of failover?

373
00:19:04.510 --> 00:19:07.892
If I lose my main link to the Internet,

374
00:19:07.892 --> 00:19:13.300
which gives me access to my cloud
provider, what do I do now?

375
00:19:13.300 --> 00:19:15.566
Am I done, is it over?

376
00:19:15.566 --> 00:19:16.948
Or do I have a failover link?

377
00:19:16.948 --> 00:19:21.641
So start looking for single points of
failure, and provide redundancy for

378
00:19:21.641 --> 00:19:25.227
them, so that it's no longer
a single point of failure.

379
00:19:25.227 --> 00:19:28.918
You can survive an outage,
at least to some extent, right?

380
00:19:28.918 --> 00:19:31.430
And of course,
if you have the money, go crazy.

381
00:19:31.430 --> 00:19:34.918
And then, the links that are there,
are they being secured?

382
00:19:34.918 --> 00:19:42.980
Is it a VPN, site-to-site capabilities of
tunneling using IPSec, or SSL, or, yeah.

383
00:19:42.980 --> 00:19:45.062
Is that happening, SSL, VPN tunnel?

384
00:19:45.062 --> 00:19:48.267
Or TLS, I guess it would be nowadays,
it should be TLS.

385
00:19:48.267 --> 00:19:51.810
[LAUGH] Don't use SSL anymore,
it's not good, right?

386
00:19:51.810 --> 00:19:55.200
But just verify that those things
are happening, so it is very important.

387
00:19:55.200 --> 00:19:57.400
>> Well how about another concept,
if it's network design,

388
00:19:57.400 --> 00:20:00.360
then one of the things I think of
is things like segmentation, right?

389
00:20:00.360 --> 00:20:04.060
The separation of certain devices,
components, resources within our network.

390
00:20:04.060 --> 00:20:05.732
Tell me a little bit about
network segmentation.

391
00:20:05.732 --> 00:20:08.918
>> Yeah it's,
hey have we not heard that already.

392
00:20:08.918 --> 00:20:10.078
Wes is right on the ball,

393
00:20:10.078 --> 00:20:12.800
he is a man that has been around
the block a couple of times.

394
00:20:12.800 --> 00:20:15.465
Network segmentation
is a very good way for

395
00:20:15.465 --> 00:20:19.760
us to be able to control the security
surrounding our networks.

396
00:20:19.760 --> 00:20:22.730
What gets in, what gets out,
who contacts who.

397
00:20:22.730 --> 00:20:27.260
And should they be able to, and if so, we
should be monitoring that contact, right?

398
00:20:27.260 --> 00:20:28.480
The ideas go on and on.

399
00:20:28.480 --> 00:20:31.114
So what are the devices that
help us do this segmentation,

400
00:20:31.114 --> 00:20:33.768
we've kinda been through this
a couple of times already.

401
00:20:33.768 --> 00:20:36.521
This is our routers, this is our switches,
this is our firewalls.

402
00:20:36.521 --> 00:20:40.680
These are the main devices in which
we use to control said segmentation.

403
00:20:40.680 --> 00:20:41.900
Every now and then you see a hub but,

404
00:20:42.900 --> 00:20:44.960
let's take those out of
your network right now.

405
00:20:44.960 --> 00:20:47.200
I demand it unless you're using it for

406
00:20:47.200 --> 00:20:50.074
like sniffing the network
as an administrator.

407
00:20:50.074 --> 00:20:54.163
I don't really see any good reason
a hub should be on your device.

408
00:20:54.163 --> 00:20:57.729
So let's talk about switches, remember
we can create VLANs for segmentation.

409
00:20:57.729 --> 00:21:02.311
So now HR traffic is on the HR VLAN, and
sales traffic is on the sales VLAN, and

410
00:21:02.311 --> 00:21:04.018
never the twain shall meet.

411
00:21:04.018 --> 00:21:07.944
Unless we stick a router in the mix and
allow for those connections.

412
00:21:07.944 --> 00:21:12.079
And then if I do have a router, now I'm
able to ACL that traffic and control that.

413
00:21:12.079 --> 00:21:15.133
Now if I have multilayer switch,
it does have ACL,

414
00:21:15.133 --> 00:21:17.271
some of them do have ACLing as well.

415
00:21:17.271 --> 00:21:21.280
So maybe I get an all in one solution
when it comes to segregating

416
00:21:21.280 --> 00:21:24.540
my traffic between VLANs and
creating VLANs.

417
00:21:24.540 --> 00:21:29.400
And then allowing for access control
lists inside of that environment.

418
00:21:29.400 --> 00:21:34.690
But typically you'll see switches, and
routers, and multilayer switches as well.

419
00:21:34.690 --> 00:21:36.674
Firewalls, don't forget
to those those in there.

420
00:21:36.674 --> 00:21:38.821
There's a couple of ways in
which we can employ firewalls.

421
00:21:38.821 --> 00:21:44.400
This is single firewalls, you've got
multi-homed firewalls basically,

422
00:21:44.400 --> 00:21:48.103
or as they call it,
multi-interface firewalls.

423
00:21:48.103 --> 00:21:51.136
And then you have multi-firewalls,
and I've got a couple of

424
00:21:51.136 --> 00:21:54.771
diagrams that I've whipped up just so
we could see how these things work.

425
00:21:54.771 --> 00:21:58.893
So let's see here,
I think this is my first one, here we go.

426
00:21:58.893 --> 00:22:02.345
This is network segmentation
with single firewall,

427
00:22:02.345 --> 00:22:04.573
this is a single firewall design.

428
00:22:04.573 --> 00:22:09.790
We've got the Internet here, and
traffic comes in and hits my router.

429
00:22:09.790 --> 00:22:14.140
And the router, we'll have
an interface that goes over to my DMZ.

430
00:22:14.140 --> 00:22:18.440
My DMZ is gonna be running things like
email, web, stuff of that nature.

431
00:22:18.440 --> 00:22:22.270
Stuff that I expect my outside world or

432
00:22:22.270 --> 00:22:25.580
outside clients to be able to
access from the outside world.

433
00:22:25.580 --> 00:22:29.960
It's not a trusted network per se.

434
00:22:29.960 --> 00:22:34.266
It's on the inside a bit, but
I expect it to be being contacted and

435
00:22:34.266 --> 00:22:38.120
reached out to and
have communications with the outside.

436
00:22:38.120 --> 00:22:41.602
Now I can put some ACL's in there to help
with that, but typically we got a router,

437
00:22:41.602 --> 00:22:43.387
we got our switch, and there's our DMZ.

438
00:22:43.387 --> 00:22:47.569
And maybe I'm separating that traffic in
the DMZ through segmentation there, or

439
00:22:47.569 --> 00:22:48.547
different VLANs.

440
00:22:48.547 --> 00:22:53.415
But once, say I've got a web server
sitting right here, and inside my internal

441
00:22:53.415 --> 00:22:57.790
network I've got a database backend,
which is a very typical design.

442
00:22:59.360 --> 00:23:03.690
You'll notice that in between that
conversation is going to be a firewall.

443
00:23:03.690 --> 00:23:06.377
And it's going to be doing IDSing and
IPSing, right?

444
00:23:06.377 --> 00:23:10.843
And it's gonna be deep
packet inspection happening.

445
00:23:10.843 --> 00:23:15.206
I'm looking at this so that at least
the traffic is run through a security

446
00:23:15.206 --> 00:23:19.869
appliance before it hits the backend
inside of my trusted internal network.

447
00:23:19.869 --> 00:23:22.792
So that's a single firewall design,
just in and out, and

448
00:23:22.792 --> 00:23:26.290
it's checking the traffic
as it passes through.

449
00:23:26.290 --> 00:23:31.220
All right let's get out of here,
and let's move on to I think this

450
00:23:31.220 --> 00:23:35.830
is the next one hopefully,
I do this right.

451
00:23:35.830 --> 00:23:40.130
Now we have a multi-homed or
multi-interface firewall.

452
00:23:40.130 --> 00:23:45.324
Now you'll notice that the design
really hasn't changed a bunch, right?

453
00:23:45.324 --> 00:23:48.060
I do also want you to know that this is,

454
00:23:48.060 --> 00:23:53.551
they'll call this a service leg firewall,
that's one of the names for it.

455
00:23:53.551 --> 00:23:58.111
So this will be the service leg
right over here with the DMZ off of

456
00:23:58.111 --> 00:23:59.674
another interface.

457
00:23:59.674 --> 00:24:02.006
So we come straight in from
the Internet to the router.

458
00:24:02.006 --> 00:24:03.835
The router passes right to the firewall,
and

459
00:24:03.835 --> 00:24:06.351
then the firewalls makes the rules
on where the traffic goes.

460
00:24:06.351 --> 00:24:09.182
This goes to the DMZ,
And I'm inspecting it.

461
00:24:09.182 --> 00:24:12.962
Now, my DMZ is getting inspected traffic,
right?

462
00:24:12.962 --> 00:24:16.500
Now when the traffic comes back and wants
access my internal network, guess what?

463
00:24:16.500 --> 00:24:20.800
I'm inspecting that, I'm inspecting
it coming in and going out, all ways.

464
00:24:20.800 --> 00:24:24.940
Now this is a very common design because,
well you got one appliance,

465
00:24:24.940 --> 00:24:28.580
and you just spend the money, get a beefy
appliance and let it handle all this.

466
00:24:28.580 --> 00:24:34.260
Put it in your modules, and
let it go buck wild, that's great, right?

467
00:24:34.260 --> 00:24:37.150
That's a really good way to
handle this cuz it's one.

468
00:24:37.150 --> 00:24:39.970
But then you gotta worry about
single point of failure,

469
00:24:39.970 --> 00:24:41.420
what if that firewall goes down?

470
00:24:41.420 --> 00:24:42.510
Do I have on site backup?

471
00:24:42.510 --> 00:24:45.460
These are all the things that
we have to take into accounts.

472
00:24:45.460 --> 00:24:50.060
But it's a really good basic design for
maybe smaller companies.

473
00:24:50.060 --> 00:24:55.360
All right, so let's take a look at the,
that's the service legs design or

474
00:24:55.360 --> 00:24:58.290
the multi interface firewall.

475
00:24:58.290 --> 00:25:01.990
Let's take a look at the last
design which is the multi firewall,

476
00:25:01.990 --> 00:25:06.850
again getting a little more complex
because we're adding appliances in here,

477
00:25:06.850 --> 00:25:08.430
and giving us a little more security.

478
00:25:08.430 --> 00:25:14.200
But really if you look at this, this
is basically the same design as before,

479
00:25:14.200 --> 00:25:15.960
you just have different
appliances doing it.

480
00:25:15.960 --> 00:25:20.770
So you might be able to be a little more
robust as far as its capabilities goes,

481
00:25:20.770 --> 00:25:22.440
you're not getting such a performance hit.

482
00:25:22.440 --> 00:25:24.790
It just depends on the devices
that you're using.

483
00:25:24.790 --> 00:25:28.447
But it's basically the same idea,
internet comes in to the router,

484
00:25:28.447 --> 00:25:32.561
router shoots it over to the firewall,
firewall sends it down to the switch.

485
00:25:32.561 --> 00:25:37.331
And then that traffic either gets over to
the DMZ, or into the internal network,

486
00:25:37.331 --> 00:25:40.590
depending on where it's designed to go.

487
00:25:40.590 --> 00:25:45.370
And if you're going into the internal
network, you hit yet another firewall.

488
00:25:45.370 --> 00:25:49.550
So, it's all about laying out
the traffic in a way that it's going to

489
00:25:49.550 --> 00:25:53.980
at least be inspected and checked in some
way, shape or form through your firewall.

490
00:25:53.980 --> 00:25:57.760
Allowing those firewall rules to
apply to it and just because you got

491
00:25:57.760 --> 00:26:00.760
a DMZ over there, doesn't mean you
shouldn't be inspecting that traffic.

492
00:26:00.760 --> 00:26:04.750
It could definitely be a precursor
to a further attack down the road,

493
00:26:04.750 --> 00:26:07.490
so it's nice to be able to
see what's happening there.

494
00:26:07.490 --> 00:26:10.600
If you've got your own firewall
dedicated for seeing that

495
00:26:10.600 --> 00:26:15.030
incoming traffic that is going over there,
then that can be a very helpful thing.

496
00:26:15.030 --> 00:26:18.030
So that being said, these are the
different types of network segmentation

497
00:26:18.030 --> 00:26:19.730
that you're gonna need to know for
the exam.

498
00:26:19.730 --> 00:26:23.850
And, that about wraps it up for
this show my man.

499
00:26:23.850 --> 00:26:26.340
>> All right,
I'm glad I had got to jump in on this one,

500
00:26:26.340 --> 00:26:28.630
been some fascinating, exciting concepts.

501
00:26:28.630 --> 00:26:32.470
I know Dan you love this stuff, you know I
love this stuff, so we'll do exactly that.

502
00:26:32.470 --> 00:26:34.640
We're gonna round this one out,
and we'll call it a day, but

503
00:26:34.640 --> 00:26:37.120
keep in mind we've got a lot
more to come in this CySA+.

504
00:26:37.120 --> 00:26:39.100
Dan as always we appreciate
having you here, and

505
00:26:39.100 --> 00:26:40.810
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

506
00:26:40.810 --> 00:26:43.210
Signing out for ITPro TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

507
00:26:43.210 --> 00:26:44.070
>> And I'm Daniel Lowrie.

508
00:26:44.070 --> 00:26:46.022
>> We'll see you next time.

509
00:26:46.022 --> 00:26:51.966
[MUSIC]

510
00:26:51.966 --> 00:26:55.325
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.
